Great video. Light functions similar to sound on your input because it's a wavelength traveling in sine. It's physically analog signal with a smooth rise/fall through out. Our data is digital to help fidelity in transfer and filter out non-digital/ natural noise signals. In the microphone we have to step back into the analog world because humans have no ability to speak true digitally. These digital waves are blocky looking because they are artificial and regulated electrically. It's easiest to probably say digital is machine data signals. My guess is the light is triggering in the data translation from analog to digital occuring at the mics.

I'm at 4:38 in the video, and I'm gonna take a guess at how they're gonna do it. The sound waves generated by someone talking in a room will cause a window to vibrate ever-so-slightly. They're going to point the laser at the window of the room, and the vibrations of the window will cause a modulation in the reflected laser. The reflected laser will be directed onto a photo sensor which can then convert those modulations back into sound waves. Now do the process in reverse using a modulated laser from the voice recording, but aim the laser at the mems microphone. The first half is a technique to CIA used to spy on the Soviet Embassy.

It looks to be just amplitude modulation on the laser beam. With such small devices, that makes sense that it would work, because of the scale of the membrane approaching the order of magnitude of the wavelength of the carrier. Photoelectric my blub. It's just normal demodulation by passive circuit (just the membrane) because of high energy (laser, hmm?) and because of the wavelength being in the same ballpark as the size of that membrane. A much better known example of this, are singing toasters and singing garage doors (yes, the actual door panes, not the electronic openers, just old fashioned unpowered garage door panes) in the vicinity of long range AM antennas. A much observed creepy issue in the 70s and 80s because of the massive increase in metal in our homes, effectively increasing the chances that one circuit will react as a tuned circuit. The effect requires metal to work, because any metal frame or structure, given the right ratio with the signal, will act like an LC circuit (inductive and capacitive effects) or an RC circuit (resistive and capacitive effects) which demodulate AM, because that's what AM does. IT IS a big thing to bring under the attention of people, showing the vulnerabilities and the absolute necessity to keep a human decision in between at all times. Not to scare you, but I wouldn't be surprised if this mechanism worked with the right microwave equipment, straight through walls and purses, outside of line of sight.

The nest IQ doesn't have built-in assistance as advertised on the package. You can not trigger lights when you come home via google app or set lights on when motion is detected. On duo sometimes the other side can't hear you and you have to call again. You can't see the cameras from the google app only from the nest app. And the google assistance in general is seriously lacking (In so many ways). You ant set your google assistant own trigger name. The only thing that does work great is the capability to tell google to clean a given room with iRobot (and even iRobot has software bugs - I had to factory reset it) Seriously, when you have 26 products in your home like I do that are supposed to be smart - you have to babysit them all the time! and this is frustrating especially when it cost so much. While they might have fixed the infinite password attempt, anyone working with password systems would know to not allow this in the first place. It just shows that security with these kind of devices isn't a priority. Even if you have to know the pin, the user is saying it aloud each time it is used and an attacker would have several ways to go about that. And while not practical yet as far as I know, it is possible to record sound through glass by recording items vibrating inside the house with a high speed camera. (But with a device in plain sight for a laser, you could just read the numbers displayed on the screen if they happen to use that device to unlock the door.)
It is highly unlikely anyone would go to such lengths to break into a random house. But that doesn't apply for targeted attacks. Two-factor authorization is moving away from SMS because there has been so many cases of it being bypassed by bribing workers in the phone companies that it is no longer considered secure.

Is it just a laser, or is the audio recording being used to modulate the laser beam - as in an AM radio transmission? In effect, the high laser frequency is filtered out - because the microphone material cannot vibrate at such a high frequency, and we are left with the audio frequency signal that is received and interpreted by the microphone.

I remember seeing, many years ago, a design for using audio to modulate car headlight beams to send 'secret' audio messages between ... maybe camp sites, teenagers' rooms at different ends of the street.

You can do something similar by adding a short message - say 10 seconds - to a 2' 40" minute audio track. That is, slow the 10 second message down so that it takes 160 seconds to play. Add it to the 2' 40" minute song. The recipient plays back the song at 16 times the normal speed. Most of the 'song' content will be too high to hear, and what is left is the 10 second message.

I've been designing transducers for a while.
Both capacitance and piezoelectric microphones use a very high impedance frontend, made with either a JFET or MOSFET transistor.
A blue laser (amplitude modulated) shone on their metallic parts will cause a photoelectric emission (same as in ancient vacuum-based photoelectric cells), which, in turns, produces a variation in electric charge, that is picked up by the input transistor.
The weakness is the high input impedance. The problem can be avoided by using a membrane type microphone, which uses a moving coil attached to the membrane. The coil is in a magnetic field, and produces a signal across a very low impedance. This cannot be attacked with a blue laser.

It takes 5 seconds for the tablet to tell you to type a different code in every time. So it would take 5000 seconds (83 minutes, 1hr 23min) just to cycle through 0-999 on a 3 digit code. four 4 digits, that would take 10 times that (about 12 hours). So, as long as the software has that 5 second delay between each allowed attempt, that vulnerability isn't a real problem in the real world. Where it would be a problem is if the door lock itself had a microphone of this type and can just be told to 'unlock' from the inside as a safety 'feature'. Presumably, especially by using lower bandwidths like infrared, the pulsating light can actually vibrate the air, though it won't produce the same soundwave a human or a speaker would produce, as far as the microphone is concerned, it's sensing the same thing. So the weakness in that system is the over- simplified microphone technology. Interesting concepts. During the Cold War, the Soviets found a way to listen in on people by shooting a laser at a window. When someone speaks, the sound would vibrate the glass in the window, and the laser would pick it up and send it back to the receiver. When the US caught on to what they were doing, they had a lot of windows to replace and reinstall so they were sound proof and non-vibrating. I think they also had tiny prisms built into the glass to refract any lasers listening in. What you did in the video is kind of the next step or next generation of that technology.

Many moons ago (1985-ish) while working on my Ph.D. in Analytical Chemistry, we studied how laser light interacted with different forms of matter. Chemical solutions, solids, etc. The phenomenon is called Photo-acoustic spectroscopy. Essentially shine a laser (tunable chemical dye laser) on a substance and record the acoustic signal with a piezo electric crystal/microphone or pressure transducer. Mems was just getting started at the time and Silicon wafer techniques were passe' because MosFet technology was taking off.



The phenomena is wavelength dependent, hence the tuneable part of the science. this was also the impetus for the laser microphone for eavesdropping.

The remote capability of the laser certainly adds some "coolness" factor, but I immediately noticed the lack of security in these devices the first time I used them, even without a laser and the covert mission to "break in" and all the hype surrounding youtube videos. It is sad that the public and even the tech sector took this long to realize how *stupidly insecure* these devices are!!! My kids immediately started issuing commands to do things that were unstoppable by any of the security features (almost nonexistent) of the Amazon Alexa. The impressive part is that an Echo Dot can pick up and understand a voice well enough even yelling through a door from over 15 feet... no laser required!! Just step up to the front door or window of a house and simply yell "Alexa, unlock front door", etc. That trick is obviously not very clandestine, but thieves could get away with it easily when everyone is gone to work and school in the neighborhood... and like anyone is really going to call the authorities if they heard someone shout that.

These manufacturers know exactly what is happening!  They should have Electrical Engineers who studied wave theory in college!  The mics are designed to respond and vibrate at frequencies within the range of the human voice. The mics are a mechanical low-pass filter (as opposed to an electronic RC circuit like your AM radio).  Ben's voice is doing AM on top of the light wave.  The low-pass filter is taking the voice command off the top of light-wave, vibrating the membranes, and passing it right into the microphone's electronic sensors.

It seems so tech-vulnerable, but most of those locks could be breached with a decent hip-bump. This would be less conspicuous than setting up an elaborate rig outside the premises and running a lengthy brute-force attack. Also, not many people would want to control someone else's air conditioning settings; though anyone with a reasonable amount of knowledge (or an internet connection to establish such knowledge) could just crack open the cover and bypass the temperature control to make it run 100% hot or cold. At the same time, it's a very impressive discovery and certainly something that would only be illuminated (have your own take regarding puns) by thinking 'outside the box'. It's certainly possible that the microphones are reacting to thermal deformation. The only thing that makes me think otherwise is the response time; for which thermal deformation is certainly not high frequency compared to typical digital signals or transducers that create such signals. The sensing circuitry is either amplified quite significantly to pick up minor deformations that translate into a fluctuating analog signal (before amplifier, filter and ADC), or the encoding of such a signal is quite forgiving (timing-wise). I can see how photons may also be responsible; but using my brain to analyze it intuitively suggests an impending headache. If infrared works, then perhaps it is indeed a thermal response; 'perhaps' being a sticky-word. Big cheers for coming up with even the idea of using this method in the first place. It's super-clever and people who think in such original ways are sure to become outstanding engineers :)

the induction of a wave over a distance is the same, whether it’s light, sound, heat, radio, etc, only the size and frequency change.

when the frequency or size of the wave is altered (the laser flashing), the energy radiating outward from the wave (loss) creates more waves (like wake) at different (slower) frequencies.

when the encoded flashes of light enter the immediate area of the microphone, the slower frequency waves given off are in or near the audible spectrum and are interpreted as sound (though the amplitude/volume is extremely low). match this with an extremely sensitive membrane, and you have laser-activated voice commands

@0:36: “So, I don’t thing there’s anything to panic or freak out about…”

Fact is; there IS!

Just about any device, big or small, comes equipped with a camera and microphone these days. Why? I don’t know!

my iMac had a camera and microphone build in from the factory. I don’t need them. I don’t use them. I actually opened up my iMac and physically disconnected the camera and microphone. Why? Because it doesn’t need to be in my computer. There is absolutely no use for these things in about 90% of the computers out there today.

“But what about Sky and things like that?”

Yes, SOME people actually find a build—in camera and microphone useful. But even out of the 10% of users who DO want a camera and microphone in their computer, the majority is using a more professional or at least higher quality version that didn’t come with their computer as standard.

In the end, over 97% of users don’t need or ever use at all the camera or microphone that is build in to their computer from the factory.

Yet, cameras and microphones are still added to just about every computer and mobile device sold today.

Why is there stuff like microphones and cameras in devices that less than 3% of the user actually need?

Possibly, here is how those microphones collect light and use it like sound.
Light is composed of photons, which are quantized packets of energy. Electrons are also quantized packets of energy. When sound hit's the diaphragm, it's result is the flow of electrons. When light hit's it, it's putting energy into the device and that get's converted as electrons. It's the same as an RTG where the heat (made of photons) from the decaying plutonium get's converted into electrons to make electricity. One and the same.

The bigger threat is having them on the same subnet as the rest of your entire house. If just one of the devices has a security flaw and is connected to the internet, you just gave adversaries a foothold in your network to pivot to your computers, phones, hard drives, etc. Those attacks are silent and no one updates the firmware on their devices. Code Red and Nimda are STILL running around the internet due to unpatched devices.

Not to sound overly-paranoid but, I'm not fully convinced that the developers of these devices were necessarily "unaware" of this capability.

This is sort of why I refuse to use any of these "smart" devices on my home. Yes they make things more convenient for you, but they are also demonstrably less secure than their traditional counterparts in virtually every way and when we're talking about locks, I would rather be semi-inconveniently secure than just the equivalent of a piece of tissue paper holding my door shut (when it comes to bypassing the locking mechanism). I genuinely think there is a place for smart devices in the home, however I don't think that is in securing the home in almost anyway because it is far easier to learn how to by pass electronics than it is to learn how to bypass an actually secure traditional lock.

comment_text:
This is probably the worst case scenario. The amount of preparation this requires makes it incredibly unlikely to be a tool for random break-ins.
The bigger problem here is that many people don't have proper security measures in place, so you can use voice commands to open their doors and get inside, at which point you're not really breaking in, just trespassing.
Also, the fact that you actually say the password out loud is a security weakness, as there is a good chance it'll be heard by someone who wasn't supposed to hear it.

If you want a good lock, get one with a restricted key.

WARNING: This video almost froze my family. Please read.

This morning, my whole family woke up to a house that was 55 degrees F (just snowed 4 inches in Colorado) my 4 children's skin was freezing anywhere that was exposed to the air. So what happened?

I looked at my Nest and it had been turned off. Somehow, my home thermostat had shut down!

I immediately looked through the Google assistant command logs to figure this out. Turns out, while watching this video the night before, my Nest got shut off as a result of this video.

Here's what happened.

With all of the "hey Google" being said during the video, I got used to saying "cancel" every time to stop my system from doing whatever Destin said. One of these times, I got a reply saying "Kitchen shut off"

Now, I was thinking that one of his commands got my kitchen Google display to play something, and I had canceled that out. Turns out it wasn't the kitchen home, but the kitchen nest!!

What an interesting problem this creates. Lateral to the point of this video, another vulnerability is presented. If there isn't proper Home Assistant hygiene in a video or during conversations we have within the MEMS' range, there can be real life consequences.

We have the Nest cranked back up, we brought up the electric heater and are cuddled around it with a huge blanket. Hopefully, those who lost their voice with the cold dry air will get it back and no one gets sick!

Light induces minority carriers in the semiconductor and the microphone is biased by a voltage. Bias voltage creates an electric field that sweeps the carriers and conduct current. Circuit can sense that current as an input signal. Laser should not provide more than necessary light flux because it could cause a saturation on the input signal. Wavelength also should be low enough so that energy of the photon is higher than the bandgap energy of material in the microphone.

Yes, this is a new and unexpected attack vector that consumers should be aware of. But consumers should also be aware that this is not a new or “smart device” problem.

Key locks, padlocks, deadbolts, reinforced doors are just a few “dumb” mechanical devices that everyone relies on for a sense of security, which can be defeated far easier and without the need of a multi-thousand dollar laser setup.

If someone is taking the time to covertly point a laser through your GLASS window, chances are your house isn’t secure enough to stop them even if you owned zero smart devices.

Smart devices can send you notifications when your door is unlocked, a video of a person entering your home, and even automatically call the cops. A glass window can’t tell you a rock just went through it, a mechanical lock can’t tell you when it’s picked. Ask a locksmith or a thief if they think it’s any harder to get inside without Alexa or Google’s help.

So I just tested it, while home assistant won't ever reject a pin code for Google Assistant, Google will get confused if it goes longer than 6 digits. BUT it also lets you select as few digits as 1. And a pin 000001 =/= 1 so the actual formula for the possible combinations of your pin number is 10^(1)+10^(2)+10^(3)+10^(4)+10^(5)+10^(6) which equals 1,111,110, times the 12 seconds I timed for me to attempt a single digit pin code, and leaving the margin of error be the extra time it takes to say a 6 digit pin instead of a 1 digit pin gives you 3703.7 hours to brute force a pin code.
That's 154 days!!

And that's assuming 24/7 brute force attempts... if you assume that people only work at this for 8 hours a day, while someone is away from their home at work, that's 462 days.
Great work !!

Everything in this world works on spectrums which are all basically vibrations/wave lengths.

Rds... a digital coding sent on the back of the audio frequencies that a rds decoder reads in the radio along with the fm receiver/decoder.
The digital tv info listing on your tv with an aerial get the tv listing sent to your tv on the back of the audio/visual spectrums.
That’s also how you see and hear..
Your brain is able to make sense of the light and audio it receives because it has the right receivers and decoders.
Your eyes and ears are like antennas and your brain decodes the vibrations/spectrums it receives.
Some animals/reptiles have the ability to see and hear things out side the spectrums we can because their brains are able to decode that frequency.

Fascinating video, but there's a much simpler attack that will work much more reliably.  A thin mobile robot with a transmitter on that sends receives light & sound.  It crawls into your home (slithers) and under remote control, the operator finds the first vulnerable device and just positions the robot as necessary.  You don't have the big alignment problems like with the laser, because the robot has a tiny speaker that transmits sound.  If you don't believe it's possible, even with a fully locked house, than you don't have any critters in your neighborhood like geckos.  Unless your home is hermetically sealed,  you're vulnerable.  And even if it is, all it takes is a small hole drilled in somewhere there is not a motion sensor or pressure alarm, and you're good to go, and that's only necessary if you literally don't have any of the following: chimney, air vents without micro-grating, etc.

Semiconductors are both photon emitters and detectors.  If any part of a device has a semiconductor exposed to a modulated light, it may cause interference in the circuits.  The manufacturers of the devices depicted in this video may have passed agency requirements for RF emissions, but obviously haven't done their homework on electromagnetic susceptibility.  It would cost pennies per unit to fix the problem, but they probably don't want to spend the money.

I think the problem as pointed out here with IoT is that we lack redundancy in these systems, which by extension means these devices also lack redundancy. If you had say, 5 microphones within one room, the system could compare the inputs, and it would be harder to spot 5 of them at once. The other issue is that the vast majority of these devices requires an internet connection to work, which means you can hack them through digital methods too (hi, Ring).

My problem when watching this video is how the experiment used lasers which are infamous when it comes to messing around with photosensitive and  frequesenitive technology.  I have no rebuttal against using lasers of course, but the major issue I actually have is how Ben is imitating vocals with lasers that can easily mimic the frequencies of an audio recording. That isn't really an exploit seeing how the real issue I have however, is how lasers aren't the only thing that can bypass the tech. Anyone who's good enough with frequencies can do it via Bluetooth, but anyone who is knowledgeable enough with frequencies can do it without any source of technology. In fact, I'd go as far to say that, the laser could have easily acted as an EMBP with that kind of set up.

Two takeaways...

1. Google really doesn’t care about security, or they wouldn’t have allowed unlimited attempts, or even verbal PIN codes at all.

2. Keep everything simple. If you don’t require a specific device or capability, get rid of it.

While they shouldn't allow unlimited pin attempts on any type of lock the brute force attack would take a VERY long time considering you have to wait for it to prompt each time. It's not as glaring of a security hole as something that was computer API based and could allow 100's or even 1000's of attempts per second like we typically think of when a company fails to account for brute forcing. Doing 1 attempt every 10 seconds like it took in the video would take about 13.8 hours to try half the 4 digit pins (0001 to 5000). That's way too long to be parked somewhere with line of sight access if you were trying to break in. They still should update the firmware to have a 30 minute lockout after 3 or 4 invalid pin attempts.

At the end of the 90s, when laser pointers were all the craze, my buddy and I would have fun pointing the lasers into or onto opaque surfaces to see how such a little light could illuminate a surface. At the time, I had a simple telephone in my room but it had a hold button. When you pressed on the button there was a red LED light that would turn on within the button showing the call was on hold. This was one of the objects we would shine the laser into because it would light up as if the the button had been pressed even though the phone was off. (We were 12 at the time, simple things amazed us!). This once while I was talking on the phone, I shined the laser into that same button and it put the call on hold as if I had pressed the button. I was able to repeat this at any time while the phone was in use. Seeing this video brought all of this back. Is there an easy explanation for why this happened? For some reason, this seemed to interest no one and I have never had an answer on this. Keep up with the great videos. Thanks.

I work with electronics and it didn’t surprise me. Light definitely affects semiconductors as long as the light reaches the PN junction. Some components even use light internally to activate for the reason of isolating circuits.

Consider also that the same tools that you can use for this attack are also the same tools you could use to conduct an acoustic eavesdropping attack.

You'd first use a laser tuned to reflect off the window and because voices vibrate the window like a speaker manifold and the laser would be effected by that vibration, with the right setup you could record audio from inside the house...

Then swapping out the laser you could issue commands in the voice of the actual authorized user.

And, if you happened to have a setup capable of "directed sound" (i.e. Sound from ultrasound) you could send your control signal to the window pane - which would become the speaker - and you could (again) issue commands in the true voice of the authorized user.

You can greatly reduce the average time to guess a pin code if you use some of the principles Richard Feynman discovered while teaching himself to crack safes. Most people will tend to use a meaningful date (birthday, anniversary, etc.) for their code. You can start there (maybe after the obvious 0000, 1111,... 9999, 1234) and reduce your initial search space. Instead of 10,000 possibilities for a four digit pin, you're looking at around 50-100 if it ends up being a year (~1900-2000+), or another 365 if it ends up being a month/day (01/01 to 12/31). There's a book called "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!" that I highly recommend which talks about this and Feynman's other exploits.

If you value your security, and you have to use a pin for something, you should really use a randomly generated number.

I used to install audio masking systems.  There are systems that apply pink noise to walls, ducts and windows because lasers can be used to read the vibrations of surfaces and  translate that to intelligible audio.  It isn't some magic that isn't understood.  It has been known for years that lasers can produce, transmit and receive data (analog or digital).  This is how fiber optics work.  Electro-mechanical movement is converted to light pulses, sent over a medium like an optical cable (or in this case air) and converted back from pulses to electro--mechanical energy.  The  only thing that scares me about lasers and home automation is that devices aren't really that smart. They rely on the user setting the interface up properly so that it only responds to proper inputs.  Your analogy about creating a hardened software and it being only as strong as  the systems it connects to is very valid in the case of smart devices.  Humans become that vulnerable link.

8. Dont have electronics visible through open windows.

I do have a smart home, with a Yale lock on the front door. Originally I did have it connected to my Alexa, but it was too easy to yell through a window (as you demonstrated) to unlock the door so my home security system with the door lock has been isolated from the rest of the smart home and can only be activated with a passcoded smart phone or a dedicated security FOB, we use NO voice when it comes to security. Of note, the Yale lock has a tamper function and after a user defined 3 tries, it trips an alert on my phone, text, and email if somebody is messing with the door lock. As an additional layer of security, we have Zwave motion sensors around the house that trip indoor lights into turning red to let us know somebody is prowling around outside, and on top of that, security camera's recording in and around the house. It can be even easier than a laser.  There is an inexpensive audio transducer that you can simple press against the glass of a window.  The transducer will turn the entire panel of glass into a speaker.  You can drive it by the earphone jack on your cell phone.  Simply play back a recording that says "Hey Google, unlock the front door", and you are in.  This will work even with the curtains drawn.  Any Google assistant in that room will respond. (same applies to other hubs).  I don't trust voice control at all.  If the hubs allowed you to change the wake-up phrase, that would add another layer of security.  If the thief doesn't know your custom phrase, they can't get the hub to respond.  Unfortunately, Google insists that you use "Hey Google" or "OK Google".  To me, it's like saying "Hey Big Brother".

All this IOT garbage does is extend your vulnerable attack surface from a physical presence to an internet facing surface. Like Destin said at the end, hooking systems together inherits all the upstream vulnerabilities.  When youre relying on a lock, programmed with whatever high level language, relying on a bunch of premade libraries,  and APIs and 3rd party servers, relying on a dozen other organizations to have their ducks in a row, there is going to be a flaw at some point, and you cant expect a reasonable person to be able to make an actual informed decision about the actual risks present.  A half dozen youtube videos and you can be well informed enough on physical security to make an informed decision about a mechanical lock, and what kind of security you want or need. "Hey, maybe I should fix that latch plate" or "Hey maybe I'll get some longer screws" Vs "Hey, maybe I want a $200 proper high security lock"    Having to do firmware updates and configure wifi settings on a light bulb isnt making my life easier no matter what the marketing pitch is trying to say.

I just did some quick and dirty back-of-the napkin style math and haphazard googling, and it looks like it might actually be radiation pressure.

MEMS membrane radius ≈ 375μm
Normal speaking volume ≈ 60dB ≈ 2 x10^-3 Pa
Gives the membrane being designed for forces from sound roughly around 8.84 x10^-7 N

From the video, it appears the laser is outputting around 26.8 mW.
From another source, I have a reference for a 500 mW laser providing radiation pressure of about 1.7x10^-6 N
Assuming the pressure scales linearly with intensity (which I do not know), 26.8 mW would provide a radiation pressure of about 9.1x10^-7 N, which places it very well in the ballpark of the MEMS membrane's sensitivity.

That is amazing and creepy. If my education serves me correctly a laser can send data very similar to an AM (Amplitude Modulation) radio transmitter. Notice the Amplitude or brightness in other words of the laser changing. It is a technique people have used to tramsmitt even music accross a laser beam (even an led!) That is then picked up by an LDR (Light Dependent Resistor) or a solar panel. The laser has a constant "amplitude" that increases or decreases proportional to the audio signal being sent. It's a type PAM (Pulse Amplitude Modulation) or a type of Light Pulse Modulation. The changing intensity is superimposed upon the constant beam intensity. While the beam is not changing there is no movement of the diaphragm so no fluctuation of the voltage accross it due to it acting as a capacitor (very similar to a standard condenser mic). The moment there is an increment of intensety or decrement of intensety the diaphragm will react accordingly as if it was a standard air pressure wave. At least that's how my setup was built and implemented. I may be absolutely wrong about how this is working in this video though so please correct me if I'm wrong.

Apple has (I supposed rather unintentionally - although they have a trillion dollars so who knows they may have secretly worked this out and aren’t big on sharing major vulnerabilities in case they are compromising) solved this issue. This was likely simply in measures to stop attack from people trying to mimick your voice, but this translate well to this sort of attack.

I speak only of them because I own their products and understand their security (it’s important you should do the same for the products you own to understand any vulnerability and how you can negate it). Hopefully some of you in the comments find this interesting.

The first precaution is of course trying to make sure only someone who sounds like you can activate the assistant (hence your intro did not create a reminder on my phone). This means that for someone to make commands to an iPhone, you have to either have a recording of them or know them and also be able to imitate their voice (hard even if you know them but they aren’t around and you didn’t just hear them speak, hence you likely need a recording as before, or are a good friend and unlikely to want to do harm).

Anyway Apple tailors the level of security for Siri based on context. The Apple Watch has the lowest level of speech recognition. Almost anyone can activate it. But it’s on your wrist all the time, and when you take it off it locks so Siri doesn’t work at all. So if it’s on your table at night charging the laser won’t work. And whilst it’s on your wrist it also won’t work - because well if someone tries to trick it whilst it’s on you can just cancel it but you’re awake to fix and issues anyway if your friend is being a pain with the lights etc. And laser won’t track a tiny mic on a moving wrist. You can also just cancel by pressing the crown.

Then next level up is iPhone. iPhone can have Siri when locked, so could be fooled by this when say it’s charging and you’re asleep. Because of this Apple increased the specificity of voice required. This is also made possible due to the larger footprint and battery of an iPhone, enabling higher quality microphones. So regardless even if you manage to trick Siri with a sort of close to voice match, you can literally do nothing. Apple needs the device unlocked. And to anyone who hasn’t used Face ID and thinks this is a pain, you’re wrong. By the time you say hey Siri into the phone it’s probably unlocked so your command happens (90% of the time) seamlessly. Definitely with it for the security benefit. So that’s watch and iPhone - id say 99% safe. and again of course you always get an audio and visual signal that Siri has been activated, so you can quickly cancel any rogue commands by hitting the right side button.

Now HomePod. Again it’s lack of voice assistant features helps it’s security. HomePod is fairly dumb as a smart speaker (music sounds great though have to say) but that means that you can’t do anything super private without explicitly turning it on without verification from your iPhone. So whilst it accepts anyone to turn on your lights, it’s not going to message your boss etc. And this leads on nicely to the recent update which added all of these features. Except again Apple was clever. HomePod sits vulnerable in the open. Not to mention the fact that you cant actually determine the position of the microphones from the outside, and I would assume the mesh fabric covering decreases the attack range. But say by some miracle you had the laser trained on the microphone. Well HomePod has the best microphones and therefore the strictest voice recognition. You would NEED a recording to play through the laser. My brother can activate Siri on my iPhone, but he can’t act as me on HomePod. It is extremely specific and vigilant. If you want to send texts or personal stuff from my phone with HomePod, you have to be me or have a recording of me. Doesn’t work like on the iPhone. Hence unless you know the person and managed to record them (in which case you are likely a friend with no bad intent) specifically saying the command and hey Siri, you’re out of luck. So like 1 in a million straight out of the gate!

So basically an attack on all of the main 3 is very difficult. I don’t know about Mac, I don’t yet have experience with a newer generation with hey Siri.

I also wonder if the waterproofing membranes on the Apple Watch and water resistant membranes on the iPhone help to block laser attacks also. That would also align with the idea that Apple Watch has the poorest microphone hence is least voice specific due to all the goop stopping water getting in, and why HomePod with none can afford to be more specific.

I’d also like to know if the HomePod mesh fabric reduces attack range, if it is possible to locate a microphone without removing the mesh jacket (of course study pictures beforehand) and whether HomePod accepts inputs where it hears sound only from one microphone, or whether Apple knew a targeted attack like this was possible and made HomePod analyse whether any of the other mics picked up a similar sound, as they would with a real person speaking.

As someone who takes privacy fairly seriously, and with Apple supposedly having your back I hope this comment stands up. And also we can find vulnerabilities, so they can be fixed or we know how to negate them.

Excellent video, id really appreciate if anyone can dispute or correct anything I’ve said, or simply add to it. Apple is certainly not perfect in security, but it’s good to know they try

It seems like they are just modulating the amplitude of the laser. I think the laser is just interacting with the metallic parts of the designs and inducing currents of amplitude proportional to laser intensity. You are basically doing the piezo's work outside the apparatus mic and inputting it straight away into the metallic contacts. Then the internal processor interprets it as if coming from the transducers. The range of wavelengths useful for this should just be limited by the casing of the mics.

I think that fixing this breach is just a matter of making a smart Faraday cage around these receivers... Maybe a metallic mesh with high optical losses...

Seems like google nest hub is the most vulnerable.  It would be pretty hard to get the laser on Alexa enabled smart speaker or smartphone.   As far as the pin goes. Attackers would not need brute force. They would use social engineering via social media or email to determine which homes have google nest installed, do a drive through at night to see which homes have google nests they can have clear shot with their laser.  Then they would have to stake out the area and wait for the home owner to say the pin.  Once they have that, they can program the laser and open a door when the home owner is not home.   I believe that a properly designed smart home should not use voice recognition to open doors.  Instead it should be via smart phone that uses biometrics such as your face or fingerprint to unlock.  Basically it would require you to use a specific phone that connects to that homes WiFi connection to determine if the phone is a authenticated device, then it will rely on the phones biometric security to authenticate the user. Only then will it unlock your door.  Voice commands should only be used to control lighting, AC, and small appliances.

This is a variation on spy techniques the US government started developing in the 1960's under the project heading "Tempest". It is also similar to techniques that hackers are still developing.

.

You mentioned "laser mikes", aimed at windows. A couple of years ago someone demonstrated aiming the laser at crumpled foil, like a chip bag, and being able to recover voice from the vibration. So if you are inside the room, but across it with no window to bounce off, you could aim at their discarded chip back to eavesdrop...

.
Or using voice recognition to translate the sound of typing on a keyboard into the actual key presses (letters)!

.
These MANY various spy techniques are really amazing. And scary.

.
A couple of days ago I was reading an article about using laser light to induce vibration in a human body to create ultrasonic images. The idea is use it in situations where touch is not possible, such as burn victims.

.

Bottom line, for the (justifiably) paranoid, it is a good idea to still not allow these spy devices into your home unless you invest time learning about hacking techniques. It's time to tape over those mikes on your "Smart TV".

.
And as much as it pains me to say, maybe it is past time for the government to step in start creating minimum security standards / regulations for various devices. Starting with the obvious, no "hard coded" passwords. The IOT needs a Ralph Naider to start forcing the government to do it's job and provide minimum safety standards for devices.

.

This situation, in reverse, was a national security risk in the 70’s and ‘80’s. It was discovered that window glass on office buildings and automobiles vibrated with the sound of the voices near them.  A laser trained on the window of, say, the White House, could pick up the conversation through that tiny vibration. This was defeated, at least initially, by installing tiny speakers in suction cups on the windows that played music or white noise into the window payne to scramble the vocal vibrations. Perhaps a similar approach could secure the electronic assistant.

In terms of how light can trigger the mic, this sounds like basically how photoacoustic spectroscopy works. When you rapidly vary a beam of light hitting something, it induces momentary localized heating which produces sound waves as the material relaxes. With photoacoustic spectroscopy, you have it be a constant blinking basically by repeatedly interupting the beam, and then you listen for how the test object releases sounds in response and it can tell you all sorts of stuff about the material being tested. With this it's the opposite. You inducing the heating to produce a specific sound. That's my bet anyway. Cool and terrifying video! I think it is a crucial point: It used to be a problem (VERY recently), not so much anymore. So as time goes on, there will be better and better security systems put into effect. Just imagine how scared people were about digital mobile phones being "so hackable" when they first came out. They are hackable, but it is getting much, much harder due to new technology.

Of course this is an endless battle like all aspects of technology. New technology is developed, hackers break it (a vulnerability is discovered), security systems are developed, they are broken too, and so on... 😊 This is why people should be aware that THIS is THE natural progression of technology. No one can claim technology is completely innocent and harmless, but also portraying it as something that is inherently evil is dangerous and misleading too. Thanks for the amazing work! These problems need to be addressed constantly (and they are) and it is important for researchers and general public to be on top of it.

Hi Dustin, what you demonstrated is a typical method called photoacoustics, where laser with variable intensity can create pressure waves (essentially sound) when confined in a space. The concept has been widely used in high-resolution phtoacoustic imaging upto centimeters insides the body. For imaging, however, red laser (690nm) is used instead of blue one. Great video as always.

This is why I get so angry at people saying we "don't need" government regulation. These devices when they were first introduced fell in a regulatory gap, with very few applicable standards and regulations on the devices themselves (even though there are some that apply to things they do, like communicating data over the internet). And like all industries that happens to, there's so many growing pains as they become more widely adopted and therefore more people expose more of their vulnerabilities, some of which would have been noticed well before in development if the companies developing them would simply have done their due diligence and try to remain within the best practices already established, and they could have started with a head start in the security game.

I just remembered something I discovered a few months ago.
If you take a small piece of thin metal (such as aluminum foil) and hit it with a lighter flame, you can get a very black coating on it with the soot (essentially poor-man's Vantablack). When I shone a bright light on it, I could hear a faint buzzing. Turns out that my flashlight (a RovyVon Aurora A3) uses PWM to drive the LED even in the highest setting. The black tin-foil was reacting to the light, and was in turn vibrating. I assume that when the light hits the black soot, the soot absorbs almost all the energy and heats up quickly. It then causes the air to heat up super quickly as well. When the light is removed, the soot and air cool down super quickly too. This could cause tiny pressure waves which are strong enough to be heard. I assume that something simmilar happens to the mics in our devices, since all of the ones you showed were either black or dark colored.

You can actually use a laser, a photosensitive diode, and some earbuds to listen to conversations in a room from hundreds of feet away. The laser needs to point at a glass surface, such as a window, and then bounce its reflection back at your diode. As long as your earbuds wires are connected to the diode, you will hear what's going on in that room from the vibrations of that room's glass window.

Fun fact: We had a smart deadbolt on our house years ago that would lock after 60 seconds. We felt this was good for security so we made sure we locked the door. In order to unlock we could ask our Amazon Echo or with our phones Bluetooth if we approached the deadbolt from outside we could tap it and the bolt would unlock. Fast-forward to when I was the only one home and went out to the curb to grab something and when I came back to the door it was locked. Took me a while to remember but my desk was right by a window with an Amazon echo sitting right there. So, I went to the window of my office, yelled for it to unlock and also yelled the passcode and sure enough it unlocked.

Needless to say I disabled to feature to use amazon to lock/unlock and had it only be able to tell me the status which of course disabled the pin code I yelled, too.

TL:DR - I yelled through a window at my amazon echo to get in my house once because I was stupid and didn’t have a key or my phone on me to unlock. I disabled the feature after knowing how vulnerable it could be.

Well OK I think it's definitely a wake up call for the companies to secure their devices and to consumers to not loose all their cautiousness in using such tech.
But you even use two factor authentication if you just login to some website. So it's absolutely mandatory to have at least that security level when opening physical doors. Someone who blindly uses a single voice command for his door acts so carelessly that I think this demonstration wasn't necessary to show that he's on the wrong track. That should be clear to everyone.
I my opinion Apple is going the right way there and others must adopt to this. Sure, faking other people's voices is already a thing, but identifying someone through his very own voice is a big step and makes those attacks harder. And then demanding fingerprints or FaceID gives you at least all the security that protects your phone already, which isn't too bad.
Speaking a 4 digit pin code out loud is so ridiculously stupid you could abandon the code altogether. I mean if you're going to laser attack someone, you could just as well listen (or just watch the display) to the code once before.

Thanks Destin. This was a very clever experiment. Very fun to watch and learn. When I was a younger student, we were bouncing lasers off of windows, vibrating from people talking in the room, to a receptor back at my location to hear that conversation. Not surprised lasers could induce a microphone or MEMS. The countermeasure to our experiments was to play music in the room very close to the window so the music would be all that was discernable via the reflections. In this case, keep devices away from windows. The cost of this is approach however is cost-prohibitive. A much cheaper approach and most likely what a burglar would do is use a car jack to spread your door jam open just enough to get your door open without ever needing to unlock the lock. As a future SED, try bouncing lasers off of things to see if conversations can be picked up. That could open some eyes too!
In my opinion, the bigger threat of "smart" devices and the ears we put in our homes and private lives is the personal data collection that is happening without us even being aware. Try the 'Facebook' experiment. With your phone out in the room say a few words repeatedly about, for example, I'd like to get a GoPro. GoPros are very cool, etc and keep saying GoPro in a sentence over and over. In about an hour, check your Facebook feed and note any amazon ads that may come up. You'll be surprised at what you see.

Not sure this means a whole lot in terms of security, or at least you guys didn't explain it well enough. If you could yell through the door to get vocal commands to the device, then it is just as vulnerable to that as hitting it with a laser.
The real vulnerability is in unsophisticated voice recognition, or if someone can clone your voice, they can either use the audio directly or set it up on the laser to get the right signal to unlock. It is interesting that you can drive a microphone with a laser but to me it doesn't mean a whole lot on its own in terms of security other than being able to get at the device from a greater distance if and only if there is line of sight.

Also, if these guys are really interested in seeing if what is driving the mems microphone is thermal or photoelectric, they can try reducing the laser fluence dramatically, and see if there is still current coming off, or do a systematic study with wavelength of the laser for a fixed low level fluence. Linear (non multi-photon) photoelectric effect should be independent of fluence and only dependent on the wavelength.
I would put my money on thermal effects, as the mems device is probably acting something like a golay cell with expansion of the gas changing the capacitance.
